story:
PLEASE VISIT US AT www.letthemcry.com

Thank you to all our backers and supporters for contributing and sharing our campaign!  

You can still help us make this film by visiting us at www.letthemcry.com



The Controversy With Sleep Training


The controversial subject of infant sleep training has yet again emerged in main stream media as New York and Los Angeles–based practice Tribeca Pediatrics are now recommending infants as young as 8 weeks old are ready to begin forms of Crying It Out. Even though most pro-sleep training advocates agree that parents shouldn't attempt the "cry it out" technique until babies are around four to six months of age, they all claim it teaches babies the "necessary" skill of "self-soothing" and claim that it's completely harmless, while the opposing side insist that ignoring a baby's cries is a form of neglect which can lead to increased cortisol levels from stress,  physical and mental trauma.  Yet most main stream media coverage tends to gloss over many of the flawed studies and promote the idea that infant (and toddler) night wakings are a problem.  Making babies sleep alone is a fairly new concept in most western societies. For thousands of years humans have parented in a style similar to other mammals and much of the world still continues to carry their babies close both day and night, and given the opportunity to be near their mother's breast so they could nurse whenever they needed.  No strict schedules, timed meals, harmful sleep training techniques, separation for long periods of time from the mother, etc.


There was also no need for a multibillion-dollar industry filled with "experts" and dozens of products (many which I bought and resold after it didn't "work").  There was no need for experts because there simply wasn't a problem to begin with.  Parents knew what infant sleep was and they also knew that night wakings was a temporary time and coped with it with much less maternal depression or anxiety that plagues most new parents today.



The Obsession with Infant Sleep Training 

Most doctors and pediatricians often recommend some form of sleep training for babies as young as a couple of months old, and are usually told that it is 100% safe. The two main forms of crying it out are The Ferber Method and The Extinction Method. Both involve allowing a baby to cry or delaying the offer of comfort.  The Ferber Method recommends timed comforting at increasing intervals (3mins, 5mins, etc).  The Extinction Method on the other hand is where you place your baby in their crib and you do not return until the next morning no matter how long they cry (unless there is something "really" wrong i.e. vomiting.  In which case most are instructed to clean up the vomit without making eye contact with your baby so you do not encourage them to vomit for attention/comfort)

I heard about the "Ferber Method" during my first year in college but it wasn't until I had my first child that I had taken the time to dig deeper on the subject.  Especially since I knew I could not let my son cry alone if I could help it.  Like most mothers, the sound of my baby crying was unbearable to listen to without doing something. I quickly found that the subject of sleep was also the main focus of most parent-to-parent conversations, because of course we all need sleep, most of us (like myself) looooooves sleep and a good amount of us don't get enough sleep as it is even pre-child.  So it's no wonder we are all obsessed with the anything that could get us a little more shut eye.  But I noticed very quickly that there was a clear sense of pressure to "train" our son or else we would cause him to be "too" dependent on us. I wonder how many parents felt that pressure and who also felt that crying it out  was an unnatural way for helping babies accomplish the holy grail of Sleeping Through The Night but felt they had no other options.  Something I hear often when speaking to any parent who has willingly or not so willingly sleep trained their children.  So I immersed myself in the world of infant sleep. And what I found was that we do not get all the information about what infant sleep naturally looks like and more importantly what sleep training really does to our babies and our bond with them.  

And yet we all have been told by someone that we must sleep train our children.  The pressure is real.  Very very real. And it's a sensitive time as new mother who is simply exhausted and to hear from medical professionals and peers that she must sleep train and that is the only way baby will learn to self-soothe is just not fair.  As I also found that there were a lot more options to help adjust our lives temporarily during the time when night time parenting is necessary.  But we are told often that co-sleeping is not only dangerous but highly damaging to our children and we are rarely told about the safe ways to co-sleep or bed share (and there are rules just as there are rules for crib sleeping i.e. no loose sheets, bumpers, toys etc.). 

This is why I am making this film.  To give parents the whole picture so they can make decisions based on the whole truth.  

I hope to make this film so we can change the narrative on infant sleep and I truly think with the amazing group of interviewees (both advisors and parents), loads of fascinating research, we will all look at parenting with much more love and acceptance and ideally help reduce a mother's odds at experiencing bouts of depression as a result of the anxiety that this sleep training epidemic has created.


Our Advisors & Interviewees 

Anthropology Department, Parent-Infant Sleep Lab, Durham University, Durham, UK

Helen Ball is Professor of Anthropology and Head of the Durham University Anthropology Department (2013-2016). Broadly defined, her research examines the sleep ecology of infants, young children and their parents. This encompasses attitudes and practices regarding infant sleep, behavioral and physiological monitoring of infants and their parents during sleep, infant sleep development, and the discordance between cultural sleep preferences and biological sleep needs. She conducts research in hospitals and the community, and contributes to national and international policy and practice guidelines on infant care (see www.dur.ac.uk/sleep.lab/). She oversees the translation of academic research on infant sleep into evidence for use by parents and healthcare staff via ISIS -- the Infant Sleep Information Source website (www.isisonline.org.uk).

Tracy Cassels is the founder and primary writer for Evolutionary Parenting. 

She obtained her B.A. in Cognitive Science from the University of California, Berkeley and an M.A. in Clinical Psychology from the University of British Columbia.  She recently finished her Ph.D. in Developmental Psychology, also at the University of British Columbia, where she both studied how certain evolutionary factors affect children’s empathic behaviour and critically evaluated our assessment of theory of mind in children.  Her academic works have been published in many peer-reviewed journals including Psychological Assessment, PLoS One, Personality and Individual Differences, Midwifery, and more. Tracy serves as an Adviser to the Children’s Health & Human Rights Partnership, a non-profit agency dedicated to ending routine infant circumcision.  She previously worked at the Canadian Council on Learning, a non-profit agency dedicated to researching myriad elements of learning across the lifespan, where her role was to critically analyse educational research to help form policy decisions at local school board and provincial government levels.  Tracy writes on the side with a group of researchers and gentle parenting advocates (including Dr. Darcia Narvaez, Dr. Kathleen Kendall-Tackett, Dr. Wendy Middlemiss, Sarah Ockwell-Smith, and Helen Stevens) who hope to expand awareness of the science and importance of attachment and evolutionary parenting.  Most importantly to her, though, she is a mother to daughter Madeleine (Maddy, age 5), son Theodore (Theo, age baby), stepson Desmond, and wife to husband Brian. 


Dr. Justin Coulson is one of Australia's leading parenting experts and is a highly sought-after international speaker and author. He and his wife Kylie are the parents of six daughters. Yes... six. And yes, they're all from the one family, and no, they aren't disappointed, nor are they going to try for a boy.

After a highly successful radio career Justin returned to school in his late 20’s where he earned his psychology degree from the University of Queensland and his PhD in psychology from the University of Wollongong. He has written multiple peer-reviewed journal articles and scholarly book chapters, as well as several books and ebooks about parenting, including the recently released #1 parenting book, 21 Days to a Happier Family (Harper Collins, 2016).

Justin is an Honorary Fellow at the Centre for Positive Psychology in the Graduate School of Education at the University of Melbourne. He is a consultant to the Federal Government’s Office of the Children’s e-Safety Commissioner, and has acted (and continues to act) in an advisory capacity to well-known organisations including Beyond Blue, the Raising Children Network, Life Education, Intel Security, The Australian Council on Children and the Media, and the Alannah and Madeline Foundation.

In addition, Justin is consistently sought after by the media for his expertise. He writes a weekly parenting advice column for Sydney’s Daily Telegraph, appears regularly on The Project, the TODAY Show, Studio 10, Mornings, and a large number of radio stations around the nation, and he is the parenting expert at kidspot.com.au, Australia’s number one parenting website.

Justin not only knows a lot about parenting and positive psychology, but he lives it. He has successfully taught each of his children to sleep in their own beds, wear clothing even when it’s hot, use the bathroom, and eat at least some of the food on their plate most of the time.

Justin and his wife, Kylie, live on the NSW South Coast. 


Brandie was the first in Canada to be accredited through Attachment Parenting International and is the current president of Attachment Parenting Canada. Brandie's wellness coaching practice and workshops are held in the greater Toronto area and Niagara region where she offers holistic wellness solutions to sleep-deprived parents, encompassing the four pillars of health: lifestyle, exercise, attitude and nutrition.  

Associate Professor of Educational Psychology at the University of North Texas

Wendy Middlemiss has conducted research and engaged in applied education practices in the areas of infant sleep, parent education, and family well-being. Her academic training and research has crossed areas of family-community interaction, developmental theory, and educational psychology, all with a focus on how to share information in a manner that supports children’s and families’ development. Dr. Middlemiss has completed research in New Zealand and Australia and has formed research exchange programs in these countries. Dr. Middlemiss’ work focuses on how to construct culturally sensitive, developmentally appropriate educational or intervention programs.

Professor of Psychology at the University of Notre Dame

Darcia Narvaez studies the  nest that humans inherit from their ancestors. Every animals has a nest for its young that matches up with the maturational schedule of the offpsring (Gottlieb, 1997). Most characteristics of the human nest are millions of years old. Humans are distinctive in that babies are born highly immature. Humanity's early nest includes breastfeeding 2-5 years, nearly constant touch, responsiveness to baby's needs, multiple adult caregivers, free play with multiple-aged playmates, social support), soothing perinatal (before, during, after birth) experiences and positive social climate.Each of these influences neurobiological development and is linked to wellbeing, social and moral capacities in childhood and adulthood.

Dr. Corrine Seeley obtained her Ph.D. in sleep Neuroscience from Queens University, specializing in the role of sleep in brain development and memory processing. She has published many research articles in well-respected, peer-reviewed journals and has given many public and academic lectures on the topic. Her research expertise includes studying the negative effects of sleep deprivation on mood and cognitive performance, sleep and decision-making, and understanding how emotional and cognitive memories are formed during sleep. Her passion for infant sleep began when she had a child of her own, and at 2 months was told to ‘let him cry’ by friends, family members and healthcare professionals. Knowing first-hand that the neural mechanisms of newborn sleep do not develop overnight (no pun intended) this approach seemed very drastic. She began to wonder:  Why is sleep expected to improve overnight and at such a young age? What other approaches can we use as parents to encourage healthy sleep for our children? Now, as a pediatric sleep practitioner and founder of Baby Sleep Solutions by Dr. Seeley, she is devoted to helping families establish healthy sleep habits using natural, gradual and gentle approaches.  Her practice is highly focused on parental education, a method that has been proven to be equally effective as CIO methods. It is her mission to make this knowledge accessible to all new and expecting parents, while encouraging parents to use educated, gentle and gradual approaches when guiding their baby toward great sleep.


Cecilia Tomori is an anthropologist with postdoctoral training in public health. Dr. Tomori’s work explores the lived experiences of health, illness, and wellbeing across cultures in service of addressing health and social inequities. Dr. Tomori is the author of the recent book, Nighttime Breastfeeding: An American Cultural Dilemma (Berghahn, 2014), based on her long-term ethnographic research (http://www.berghahnbooks.com/title.php?rowtag=T...). The book draws on anthropological, historical, and feminist perspectives to investigate the cultural tensions surrounding nighttime breastfeeding and infant sleep practices in the U.S. 


What We Need & What You Get

This project is nothing without a community base. We need people to not only be in the film but also we rely on the people behind the scenes to make this film. And that includes our incredible backers. We need your help to get this project off the ground. In order to start filming we need to travel and film on location to capture not only the experts interviews but also everyday moms and dads. We also want to provide real tangible solutions to handling night time parenting and all of this will take time and resources to make this film happen. We also need to sift through thousands of pages of data, research, and history to make this film factually accurate and something that can be used as resource for any parent who is considering sleep training their baby.
Even if we do not reach our entire goal we will use what is raised to start filming and capture as much as we can and use the footage to leverage private investors to complete the film.

We need to send the crew to the following places - Maryland, California, Indiana, Texas, British Columbia, Ontario, England, and Australia. We have stories in these places and much more. If we surpass our goal we would also love to send our crew to film how the rest of the world parents and deals with disturbed sleep during infancy.  Ideally to show a global perspective on night time parenting.  

Team Co-Sleep


Official Backer




Risks & Challenges

Our main risk is trying to create change in the medical recommendations given by most doctors.  We know this may not happen over night but simply starting a dialogue can hopefully entice some sort of lasting effect.  

  • We have amazing advisors who have spent a great deal of their careers studying the effects of sleep training, infant sleep, and maternal bonds 
  • We also have film industry professionals who are ready and willing to be mentors in this journey and have offered assistance and valuable advice that we think will give this film a great advantage


We hope that by sharing important stories and speaking with industry professionals we can raise awareness about sleep training and provide parents the information they deserve.  We hope to make a change.  We hope that this film will bring us back to trusting in our natural instincts.  And we hope this film will give both mothers and fathers permission to be responsive to their children, no matter the time of day or night.  

Other Ways You Can Help


In order to make this documentary, aside from funding, we need people who would like to share their experiences with sleep training (or the pressure to sleep train) to star in our documentary. All stories will be reviewed and picked out those most relevant to our subject.

We welcome stories from all over the world 

Send us your story to:

letthemcryfilm@gmail.com

Spread The Message! 

Even if you are unable to make a pledge you can still help us by getting the message out there!  Share this campaign on your social media platforms, encourage friends and family to make a difference and help us make this film a movement! 

Like us on Facebook!

Let's make a change together!

Thank you for your support.
story_txt:
PLEASE VISIT US AT www.letthemcry.com

Thank you to all our backers and supporters for contributing and sharing our campaign!  
You can still help us make this film by visiting us at www.letthemcry.com




The Controversy With Sleep Training


The controversial subject of infant sleep training has yet again emerged in main stream media as New York and Los Angeles–based practice Tribeca Pediatrics are now recommending infants as young as 8 weeks old are ready to begin forms of Crying It Out. Even though most pro-sleep training advocates agree that parents shouldn't attempt the "cry it out" technique until babies are around four to six months of age, they all claim it teaches babies the "necessary" skill of "self-soothing" and claim that it's completely harmless, while the opposing side insist that ignoring a baby's cries is a form of neglect which can lead to increased cortisol levels from stress,  physical and mental trauma.  Yet most main stream media coverage tends to gloss over many of the flawed studies and promote the idea that infant (and toddler) night wakings are a problem.  Making babies sleep alone is a fairly new concept in most western societies. For thousands of years humans have parented in a style similar to other mammals and much of the world still continues to carry their babies close both day and night, and given the opportunity to be near their mother's breast so they could nurse whenever they needed.  No strict schedules, timed meals, harmful sleep training techniques, separation for long periods of time from the mother, etc.



There was also no need for a multibillion-dollar industry filled with "experts" and dozens of products (many which I bought and resold after it didn't "work").  There was no need for experts because there simply wasn't a problem to begin with.  Parents knew what infant sleep was and they also knew that night wakings was a temporary time and coped with it with much less maternal depression or anxiety that plagues most new parents today.










The Obsession with Infant Sleep Training 

Most doctors and pediatricians often recommend some form of sleep training for babies as young as a couple of months old, and are usually told that it is 100% safe. The two main forms of crying it out are The Ferber Method and The Extinction Method. Both involve allowing a baby to cry or delaying the offer of comfort.  The Ferber Method recommends timed comforting at increasing intervals (3mins, 5mins, etc).  The Extinction Method on the other hand is where you place your baby in their crib and you do not return until the next morning no matter how long they cry (unless there is something "really" wrong i.e. vomiting.  In which case most are instructed to clean up the vomit without making eye contact with your baby so you do not encourage them to vomit for attention/comfort)


I heard about the "Ferber Method" during my first year in college but it wasn't until I had my first child that I had taken the time to dig deeper on the subject.  Especially since I knew I could not let my son cry alone if I could help it.  Like most mothers, the sound of my baby crying was unbearable to listen to without doing something. I quickly found that the subject of sleep was also the main focus of most parent-to-parent conversations, because of course we all need sleep, most of us (like myself) looooooves sleep and a good amount of us don't get enough sleep as it is even pre-child.  So it's no wonder we are all obsessed with the anything that could get us a little more shut eye.  But I noticed very quickly that there was a clear sense of pressure to "train" our son or else we would cause him to be "too" dependent on us. I wonder how many parents felt that pressure and who also felt that crying it out  was an unnatural way for helping babies accomplish the holy grail of Sleeping Through The Night but felt they had no other options.  Something I hear often when speaking to any parent who has willingly or not so willingly sleep trained their children.  So I immersed myself in the world of infant sleep. And what I found was that we do not get all the information about what infant sleep naturally looks like and more importantly what sleep training really does to our babies and our bond with them.  

And yet we all have been told by someone that we must sleep train our children.  The pressure is real.  Very very real. And it's a sensitive time as new mother who is simply exhausted and to hear from medical professionals and peers that she must sleep train and that is the only way baby will learn to self-soothe is just not fair.  As I also found that there were a lot more options to help adjust our lives temporarily during the time when night time parenting is necessary.  But we are told often that co-sleeping is not only dangerous but highly damaging to our children and we are rarely told about the safe ways to co-sleep or bed share (and there are rules just as there are rules for crib sleeping i.e. no loose sheets, bumpers, toys etc.). 


This is why I am making this film.  To give parents the whole picture so they can make decisions based on the whole truth.  

I hope to make this film so we can change the narrative on infant sleep and I truly think with the amazing group of interviewees (both advisors and parents), loads of fascinating research, we will all look at parenting with much more love and acceptance and ideally help reduce a mother's odds at experiencing bouts of depression as a result of the anxiety that this sleep training epidemic has created.


Our Advisors & Interviewees 


Anthropology Department, Parent-Infant Sleep Lab, Durham University, Durham, UK
Helen Ball is Professor of Anthropology and Head of the Durham University Anthropology Department (2013-2016). Broadly defined, her research examines the sleep ecology of infants, young children and their parents. This encompasses attitudes and practices regarding infant sleep, behavioral and physiological monitoring of infants and their parents during sleep, infant sleep development, and the discordance between cultural sleep preferences and biological sleep needs. She conducts research in hospitals and the community, and contributes to national and international policy and practice guidelines on infant care (see www.dur.ac.uk/sleep.lab/). She oversees the translation of academic research on infant sleep into evidence for use by parents and healthcare staff via ISIS -- the Infant Sleep Information Source website (www.isisonline.org.uk).

story:
Summary

The Race Across America is widely recognized as the toughest race in the world.  RAAM is a 3,000-mile coast-to-coast bicycle race that starts in Oceanside, CA and finishes in Annapolis, MD.  RAAM has become an iconic American event.  First run in 1982, the race has continued uninterrupted.  The 2016 race will be its 35th year, making it one of the longest running events in cycling sport.  Racers and crew come from around the world to compete.  Why is RAAM so compelling?  Why do racers and crew keep coming back, year after year?  Why is RAAM – an iconic American event, a world class event – recognized worldwide but largely unknown in the USA?  Over the years, many films have been made, but none have answered these questions.  No film has ever captured what makes RAAM so special.  That story needs to be told.

Our team

The Race: We have deep and wide ranging experience.  We count among us a racer and crew chief with record setting solo and team finishes.  Our group includes a successful documentary film-maker, race director and event owner.  Nobody is better equipped to tell that story than we are.

The Movie: Nothin' But Shorts International, the film maker, is an Australian company with the idea of film is all at once simple, creative and unique. Taking an idea and transforming it into a form that pleases the eye and excites the mind. Here are some samples of their work -

RAAM BAM THANK YOU MAM TEASER
https://vimeo.com/133012085

NBSI SHOWREEL
https://vimeo.com/30113535


RAAM 2016 RACERS

The Solo Contenders - Men:
Mark Pattinson (UK) - 5-tim RAAM racer with 3 second place finishes and rookie of the year; David Haase (USA) - 5-time RAAM racer, 2nd in 2015; Marko Baloh (Slovenia) - 7-time RAAM racer with 2 third place finishes & World Record Holder; Gerhard Gulewicz (Austria) - 10-time RAAM racer with 2 second & 2 third place finishes; Ralph Diseviscourt (Luxembourg) - Rookie - winner Race Across Italy, Tortour & Dolomitica

The Solo Contenders - Women:Seana Hogan (USA) - 6-time RAAM champion; Juliana Buhring (Germany) - Rookie -  Guinness around the world record holder & winner Transcontinental Race; Nicole Reist (Switzerland) - Rookie - Tortour  & Race Around Austria winner.

The Team Contenders:ViaSat (USA) - An 8-Person corporate team back for their 10th year and one time record holders; Special Unified Lions (Germany) - An 8-Person team with multiple years of experience and strong finishes; Team Working Nation (USA) - Returning 4-Person champions and overall winners looking for to break the 4-Person record.

What we need/where the money will go

We are looking for $30,000 to fund this film project.  Those funds will be spent approximately as follows:  50% production, 25% post-production and 25% marketing.  Funds raised in excess of what we seek will go toward distribution.

The plan of distribution

Premier screening in Boulder, distribution of HD digital download and signed DVD premiums to those helping fund the project, entry into film festivals, theater showings and other distribution channels.

What you get

Donate and receive the following:

$10 - Exclusive Film Decal

$20 – HD Digital download of the film

$50 - HD digital download + your name in the credits

$75 – DVD signed by the 2016 Solo RAAM winner + your name in the credits

$100 – Limited edition 2016 RAAM 35th RAAM Anniversary tee-shirt + DVD signed by the 2016 Solo RAAM winner + HD digital download + your name in the credits

$250 – Signed limited edition 11x17 2016 RAAM 35th Anniversary poster + Limited edition 2016 RAAM 35th RAAM Anniversary tee-shirt + DVD signed by the 2016 Solo RAAM winner + HD digital download + your name in the credits

$1,000 – Your company name and logo in the credits

Most importantly, you will have the satisfaction of helping us tell the story of RAAM – the world’s toughest bicycle race, why it is so compelling, why participants keep returning year after year.

What happens if we don’t reach our funding goal?

We will make the film and do the best possible with limited resources to market and distribute the film.

The impact of this project

Despite RAAM being recognized and respected around the world, this truly iconic American event is relatively unknown in the US.  While most people understand how sport builds bridges, few in America understand RAAM and the role it plays in the sports world.

There have been many RAAM videos/films made over the years – some pretty good.  But none have captured the spectacle of RAAM, the grandeur of the American landscape.  Most Americans have little knowledge of RAAM, why people come from all over the world to participate in this race, and why its fans are so thoroughly engaged.

Most people with knowledge of RAAM learned of it years ago when it was limited to solo racers, when it was covered by ABC Wide World of Sports.  But RAAM has evolved.  While solo racers remain the focus of many, teams are increasingly becoming the story today, how racers and crew work together to accomplish a shared goal, which will become a life experience like no other.  Team racing has made the world’s toughest bicycle race more accessible.

Risks/Challenges

Risks/Challenges fall into three broad categories – 1) capturing enough good footage to tell the story, 2) being able to edit the footage into a compelling product, and 3) being able to sell/distribute the final product.

Capturing enough good footage is a challenge for all live sporting events.  There are no “do overs” – either you capture the action or you don’t.  The problem is more of a challenge with RAAM.  Racers and their support crews keep going - day and night – through all types of weather. They can be separated by hundreds of miles.

You can’t cover everyone - who do you cover?  You hope those you focus on don’t drop out leaving you with half of a story.

We believe we are uniquely qualified to address these challenges and produce a compelling film which will achieve our objectives.  There is no one more knowledgeable about the race and its participants than anyone else. With a wide range of sources to draw from, access to all the riders and support crews,  volumes of historical and other background material.  Nobody is better positioned to make a film like this.

Other ways you can help

RAAM brings people together.  RAAM is a shared experience like no other.  Be a fan. Follow the Race. Become part of the RAAM family.  Help us tell the story.

Of course, we want you to contribute.  But, whether you can contribute financially or not, we need you to help spread the word.  Please help tell our story.  Tell your friends.  Share, share, share!

Taking an idea and transforming it into a form that pleases the eye and excites the mind. Here are some samples of their work -RAAM
BAM THANK YOU MAM TEASERhttps://vimeo.com/133012085NBSI
SHOWREELhttps://vimeo.com/30113535RAAM 2016 RACERS
The Solo Contenders - Men:Mark Pattinson (UK) - 5-tim RAAM racer with 3 second place finishes and rookie of the year; David Haase (USA) - 5-time RAAM racer, 2nd in 2015; Marko Baloh (Slovenia) - 7-time RAAM racer with 2 third place finishes & World Record Holder; Gerhard Gulewicz (Austria) - 10-time RAAM racer with 2 second & 2 third place finishes; Ralph Diseviscourt (Luxembourg) - Rookie - winner Race Across Italy, Tortour & DolomiticaThe Solo Contenders - Women:Seana Hogan (USA) - 6-time RAAM champion; Juliana Buhring (Germany) - Rookie -  Guinness around the world record holder & winner Transcontinental Race; Nicole Reist (Switzerland) - Rookie - Tortour  & Race Around Austria winner.The Team Contenders:ViaSat (USA) - An 8-Person corporate team back for their 10th year and one time record holders; Special Unified Lions (Germany) - An 8-Person team with multiple years of experience and strong finishes; Team Working Nation (USA) - Returning 4-Person champions and overall winners looking for to break the 4-Person record.



What we
need/where the money will go
We are looking for $30,000 to fund this film project.  Those funds will be spent approximately as
follows:  50% production, 25%
post-production and 25% marketing.  Funds
raised in excess of what we seek will go toward distribution.
The plan of
distribution
Premier screening in Boulder, distribution of HD digital
download and signed DVD premiums to those helping fund the project, entry into
film festivals, theater showings and other distribution channels.
What you get
Donate and receive the following:
$10 - Exclusive Film Decal
$20 – HD Digital download of the
film
$50 - HD digital download + your
name in the credits
$75 – DVD signed by the 2016 Solo
RAAM winner + your name in the credits
$100 – Limited edition 2016 RAAM 35th
RAAM Anniversary tee-shirt + DVD signed by the 2016 Solo RAAM winner + HD
digital download + your name in the credits
$250 – Signed limited edition 11x17
2016 RAAM 35th Anniversary poster + Limited edition 2016 RAAM 35th
RAAM Anniversary tee-shirt + DVD signed by the 2016 Solo RAAM winner + HD
digital download + your name in the credits
$1,000 – Your company name and logo
in the credits
Most importantly, you will have the satisfaction of helping
us tell the story of RAAM – the world’s toughest bicycle race, why it is so
compelling, why participants keep returning year after year.
What happens
if we don’t reach our funding goal?
We will make the film and do the best possible with limited
resources to market and distribute the film.
The impact of
this project
Despite RAAM being recognized and respected around the
world, this truly iconic American event is relatively unknown in the US.  While most people understand how sport builds
bridges, few in America understand RAAM and the role it plays in the sports
world.
There have been many RAAM videos/films made over the years –
some pretty good.  But none have captured
the spectacle of RAAM, the grandeur of the American landscape.  Most Americans have little knowledge of RAAM,
why people come from all over the world to participate in this race, and why
its fans are so thoroughly engaged.
Most people with knowledge of RAAM learned of it years ago
when it was limited to solo racers, when it was covered by ABC Wide World of
Sports.  But RAAM has evolved.  While solo racers remain the focus of many,
teams are increasingly becoming the story today, how racers and crew work together
to accomplish a shared goal, which will become a life experience like no other.  Team racing has made the world’s toughest
bicycle race more accessible. 
Risks/Challenges
Risks/Challenges fall into three broad categories – 1)
capturing enough good footage to tell the story, 2) being able to edit the
footage into a compelling product, and 3) being able to sell/distribute the
final product.
Capturing enough good footage is a challenge for all live
sporting events.  There are no “do overs”
– either you capture the action or you don’t. 
The problem is more of a challenge with RAAM.  Racers and their support crews keep going -
day and night – through all types of weather. They can be separated by hundreds
of miles.
You can’t cover everyone - who do you cover?  You hope those you focus on don’t drop out
leaving you with half of a story.
We believe we are uniquely qualified to address these
challenges and produce a compelling film which will achieve our objectives.  There is no one more knowledgeable about the race and
its participants than anyone else. With a wide range of sources to draw
from, access to all the riders
and support crews,  volumes of
historical and other background material. 
Nobody is better positioned to make a film like this.
Other ways you
can help
RAAM brings people together. 
RAAM is a shared experience like no other.  Be a fan. Follow the Race. Become part of the RAAM family.  Help us tell the story.
Of course, we want you to contribute.  But, whether you can contribute financially
or not, we need you to help spread the word. 
Please help tell our story.  Tell
your friends.  Share, share, share!

story:
The Pitch

Letters to Daniel is an independent motion picture to based upon the memoir, zero budget, proof of concept documentary and ultimately the screenplay by the women who lived the true story of two best friends and creative partners whose friendship and writing partnership withstood the test of mental illness and came out on the other side bestselling authors and award winning screenwriters and filmmakers.

 

My name is Amy McCorkle. I have bipolar disorder. Seventeen years ago I suffered a bipolar breakdown. My only ally for a year was my writing partner and best friend Melissa Goodman. When I cried it was hours. When I was angry it full on unadulterated rage. I threw things at her. Threatened her. We lived on 15 dollars a week in groceries. Met a man high on something wearing only a purple sock and have faced enemies from without and most importantly from within.
The money will go directly to all aspects of film production. Five hundred dollars isn't a lot but I have to start somewhere my reach of friends and family isn't as wide as others but they are strong in my corner.
My struggle to recovery from bipolar diorder has a long and arduous one, one that many undertake everyday and struggle to put more good days together than bad days. 5 Million Americans are diagnosed with bipolar disorder. There are others out there thinking they are alone and without hope. I am here, the film is here to show them that they are not.

What We Need & What You Get

 Ultimately the film will cost more than $500 but this is where we start.

The money will go to rental fees for cameras, lighting, paperwork, feeding the cast and crew, sd cards, and post production fees.

$5 Perk includes a personal shoutout on twitter.

$10 Perk includes a thank you and a shout out on twitter and FB

$25 Perk includes a thank you, a shoutout on twitter and FB and 2 passes to a special sneak preview of Letters to Daniel

$50 includes a thank you, a shoutout on twitter and FB, 2 passes to a special sneak preview of Letters to Daniel and a Healing Hands Entertainment Presents Letters to Daniel poster. (11x17)

The Impact

  1 in 5 people will be diagnosed with a mental illness in their lifetime. This film is meant to raise awareness and erase the stigma associated with it.

Having lived with a bipolar diagnosis for seventeen years I have lived both with the ignorance of some and the outright discrimination of others. I still face the ignorance and that is why I am so passionate about this film and getting it made.


Risks & Challenges

 An independent film is a huge undertaking. Just to stick your neck out to make a film is daring. To hire the right cast, crew, and put the right production team together is huge. Financially speaking film is the most expensive art form and for people on disability (such as myself) and working day jobs (such as Melissa) it is usually only the burning desire to tell your story that drives you to take such a risk.  So this is why we look to crowdfunding to help bring this true story to life.

Other Ways You Can Help

 If you are unable to give simply sharing this campaign on FB and Twitter will be just as helpful and important as a financial donation.

story:
Why Donate?

There are many wonderful relief efforts underway to provide food and shelter in the wake of Cyclone Winston. These are very necessary. Loloma Levu aims to raise enough to restore entire communities to get them back on their feet and to help make them self sustainable again - schools, healthcare centers, churches and homes.

Summary

Cyclone Winston, a category 5 cyclone, has left a trail of death and widespread destruction in its wake and our people need help. NOW.

A remote region called the Yasawa Islands was one of many regions in Fiji to be devastated by Winston. More than 90% of staff employed by The Barefoot Collection come from villages in this region. Apart from the emotional trauma and loss of life, they now also face the threat of water-borne diseases, dengue, chikungunya and Zika, if their communities and utilities are not restored.

In order to mobilise our partners, friends and guests to assist our communities, we have established the Loloma Levu Fund.

“Loloma” is Fijian and most commonly translates to love or mercy and “levu” means big, great, large or many. In many cases, the expression “loloma levu” is an idiom,  meaning "lots of love" and in the context of this campaign, we hope that many people all over the world can, through a small (or big!) gesture, show their support by helping to rebuild 6 villages.

6 Villages. 60 Days. $6 million.  That’s 1 million people donating just $6!

 What We Need 

We have set a target of $1 million per village, to rebuild homes, the healthcare centre, restore utilities like water tankers and sanitation, and infrastructure. The villages we are supporting that have been hardest hit are Namara, Naboro, Yamata, Kese, Muaira and Soso.

Funds will be distributed by The Prime Ministers Disaster Relief Fund and whatever is raised will be equally distributed between these villages.

The Impact

The Kese Health Centre was established in 1970 and supports five settlements, seven schools and five villages. It is staffed by one nurse and one doctor and helps roughly 500 children and 315 pregnant women each year. Much of the support provided is for maternal, infant care and community health. The center has two beds and also assists with common injuries like cuts and lacerations.

The Namara Village School & Kindergarten was founded in 1980. The school serves 85 children from ages 3 through 13 years old. There are four classrooms and four teachers teaching eight classes, as two grades are taught together in each room. Once the children finish their primary education, the majority then attend boarding school on the main island of Vitu Levu for their high school education.

The Muaira Village Library was established 1 year ago and operates from the primary school in Muaira Village. The primary school serves 77 children from the ages of 3 through 14 years old. The Muaira Village Library provides literature and academic support material for the inhabitants of Kese (251 people) and Muaira (165 people).

These vital community resources have destroyed and will need to be re-built from the ground up. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't make a donation, there are other ways to help, too:

  • Travellers to Fiji can also help by bringing supplies for Pack for a Purpose:  http://www.thebarefootcollection.com/community/...
  • Help us to get the word out and share, share, share! Send this link to your friends, schools, radio stations, media and everyone in your community
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools in the navigation bar on the left, to share on Facebook, Twitter or to embed and link back from your site.
Vinaka Vaka Levu, from all of us!

Credits

This campaign was made possible by these special, generous, talented people. They generously donated their time, content and expertise. From the very bottom of our hearts, Vinaka Vaka Levu.

  • Photography: Benjamin Von Wong, Anna Tenne, Marie Le Coze, Thomas Vignaud, Joost Glaser
  • Content Production: Tom London - mormormedia
  • Sound Design : Tom London - mormormedia
  • Graphic Design & Iconography: Alex Gordon
  • Drone operator: Joost Glaser
  • Social Media Advice : Christine Beggs

story:
Humans & Cats

In our interactions with the natural world, humans and cats share a unique relationship. They have been deified by us and as often, vilified by us. They heal us with purr therapy and threaten the unborn with toxoplasmosis. When they are characters in our stories, their traits mimic us more than when we anthropomorphize other animals such as dogs. Cats are aloof and curious and self-interested and affectionate and have moods, whereas dogs are just always happy, maybe how we wish we were.

The Conflict

New Zealand has the highest per capita cat ownership of anywhere in the world. As an island, it has also provided isolation for the evolution of many species that exist nowhere else in the world. The cats, both feral and domesticated, are killing off many endangered endemic species - bats, birds, rodents, penguins - many of which are on the brink of extinction. There is a current movement to convince all Kiwis to commit to giving up their cats, first by sterilizing the ones they have and then not pursuing ownership in the future. Since cats are often part of the family, however, this is a serious and sad prospect to contemplate, much less agree to as a nation.

Our Story

“Goodbye to All Cats” is the story of convincing the country that loves them most to banish the sweet, familial, adorable, vicious, prolific killers to protect their unique diversity that doesn’t purr.

We will be traveling to New Zealand in late April to do our principle shooting for one month. We have lined up interviews with the leader of the Cats to Go movement, as well as prominent scientists, conservationists, cat owners and defenders of the cat presence in New Zealand. We have a shooting schedule and travel arrangements. We have already funded 50% of the project--we now need to secure the remaining funding in order for the project to move forward. That's where you come in!

story:
Short Summary

"People fear or hate what they don't understand. We judge without understanding". 

Hi, I’m Marcus Lucas the Writer and Director of TATTED SOULS. I was asked to work on this project by Shonda Harris our Producer to tell a story about exotic dancers in the LGBT community. I have to admit not being familiar with the LGBT community, I was kind of hesitant at first, but having further conversations with Shonda and my niece Raine Lucas Co-Writer and Producer, with much thought ,we were able to write about true life events and stories. 

The Story 

With this film, we hope to start a healing process by telling you a story about a small town girl, a preacher’s daughter, named Sarah,  in her first year of college in the big city to study to be a journalist. Her Professor asks the students to find a story to write about and be graded by the end of the semester.  Sarah meets and writes about Kand’e and other exotic dancers in the LGBT community who are navigating their way through life, fighting past their childhood demons. Sarah who is  fighting religion and acceptance is intrigued and she develops an intimate relationship with Kand’e’. Sarah falls in love and starts to questions her faith.

Martin Luther King, Jr., Strength to Love 


“Like an unchecked cancer, hate corrodes the personality and eats away its vital unity. Hate destroys a man's sense of values and his objectivity. It causes him to describe the beautiful as ugly and the ugly as beautiful, and to confuse the true with the false and the false with the true”.


What Your Contribution Means

This budget will allow us to cover other costs such as:

Cast & Crew

Props

Costumes

Transport to and from location

Catering.

Music Rights and Licensing

Equipment Rentals 

Editing Fees (includes color grading, color and sound correction) 

Travel and Lodging (Oklahoma and Miami, Florida)

Distribution

Applications to Film Festivals

Attorney Fees

Perks Reward

Crowdfunding Fees

Our Timeline

We've already mapped out our shooting locations plan for TATTED SOULS, and it goes like this:

Sepetember 2016: we'll start filming TATTED SOULS  in Oklahoma, Texas, and Miami.

December 2016: after editing, we'll submit the finished cut of TATTED SOULS  to one of the world's major international film festivals and submissions to many more festivals in 2017. If TATTED SOULS  gets accepted into one of these prestigious festivals, our chances of getting a worldwide DVD/Blu-ray distribution deal will increase dramatically. 



SHONDA HARRIS:  PRODUCER & ASSISTANT DIRECTOR 

Began her Professional Entertainment career at age 12 dancing for the Jacksons Victory Tour celebrity fashion show in Los Angeles, where she was introduced to the Jackson family and many other celebrities.  At the age of 15 Shonda joined the group Destiny Master Crew (DMC) sponsorship by Ozarka ®. DMC Toured over Texas, which lead to special guest appearances.  Shonda graduated top 10 of her class in 1998 and her pictures still hangs today on the wall of fame at Le Cordon Bleu Texas in 2009 where she was reintroduced to the world of entertainment. In just two years time, her company Talent Beyond Belief was well known as the go to Media outlet. 2010 Shonda began to write several scripts all based on true stories from her life the first being ‘A Better Lyfe’ which premiered during SXSW 2014 to a sold out crowd.

MARCUS LUCAS:  WRITER & DIRECTOR

 In 1990 studied film at Golden State School in Chatsworth, CA , and photography at Santa Monica College. Worked on projects with F. Gary Gray Director of Friday and Straight of Outta Compton. In 1996 freelance for BET Sports, moved to Dallas, TX  in 2009 started Precious Memories Editing Video & Photography (P.M. Editing) filming and editing wedding, and Internet commercials. 

    

RAINE LUCAS: CO-WRITER, PRODUCER & CASTING DIRECTOR

Studied business management at the University of Texas at Arlington. Her first credit co-writing a  screenplay based on true events. She brings a lot of creative and personal energy to the team and is also instrumental in wanting to share this project on a global scale.  


Risks & Challenges

There are a lot of challenges that go along with filmmaking -most of them are unpredictable.  

To overcome this challenge, we will strive to make sure that all filming is done in a professional and timely manner. 

We would like to state again just how much our hearts are in this project, and that we are entirely committed to completing this project. We will do everything humanly possible to overcome any obstacle that we come up against so that we can share TATTED SOULS with the world!


Other Ways You Can Help

Share our campaign with everyone you know! Every bit counts.

Use the Indiegogo share tools! Send notes to your friends, family, colleagues and acquaintances by email and texts. We are asking that you talk about TATTED SOULS every chance you get.

So lets start to understand and remove the hate. Thank you for visiting our fundraising campaign page for our emotional story, and no matter what path or journey you take love is the key.

We will do everything humanly possible to overcome any obstacle that we come up against so that we can share TATTED SOULS with the world!


Other Ways You Can Help
 
Share our campaign with everyone you know! Every bit counts.Use the Indiegogo share tools! Send notes to your friends, family, colleagues and acquaintances by email and texts. We are asking that you talk about TATTED SOULS every chance you get.
So lets start to understand and remove the hate. Thank you for visiting our fundraising campaign page for our emotional story, and no matter what path or journey you take love is the key.

story:
The Right of Muslim Women to Marry Outside the Faith

Our Story

“Love has no boundaries and women have equal rights to men to choose who they want to marry.”

This is the core message of a series of short films being produced by Ibn Rushd Media Productions, an independent media company that promotes a progressive vision of Islam. The video series centers on the theologically-grounded argument that Muslim women have the same rights as Muslim men to marry outside the faith—a view currently not held by the majority of Muslim scholars. 

The first of these short films is a two-part interview with Muslim scholar, Dr. Ahmed Subhy Mansour, who is licensed to perform marriages in Virginia and has officiated several of these interfaith marriages between Muslim women and non-Muslim men. The second film is a short promo, which gathers the opinions of different young professional Muslims and non-Muslims who live in the United States to discuss their experiences with love, dating, and marriage as a religious minority in the U.S. The third short film, which will be released later, is the first in a broader fictional series we are calling “Leila and Keith” (our play on the famous Arab love story “Leila and Qais,” which tells the story of Leila and her struggle to marry a non-Muslim man, Keith. 

 What We Need & How You Can Help

Ibn Rushd self-funded the production of the first three films.  We are hoping to raise a total of $25,000.00 through this Indiegogo campaign to produce at least five more short films in both fictional and interview format to further discuss the issue from other angles. Any funds raised beyond the initial $25,000.00 will go towards producing a longer documentary about the topic. 

We also greatly welcome IN-KIND DONATIONS. Let us know if you'd like to offer any creative services, legal advice, video production and editing, translation services, subtitling services, access to news footage, music, or anything else that you think can help. We are also looking for volunteer actors and actresses. Email Info@ibnrushdmedia.com with the subject line: "In Kind", if you'd like to discuss these possibilities.

We will host a screening of the three short films and an open discussion event in Washington D.C. in the summer of 2016 to share with a wider audience the story behind establishing Ibn Rushd Media and other behind-the-scenes stories and clips. The exact date of the screening will be announced in late June, 2016. We also want to hear your feedback on the films, the issues, and any personal experiences with interfaith marriage you may want to share. In the meantime, we highly encourage you participate in our online discussions to hear your stories and feedback, using the hashtag #HerRight2Marry on our Facebook page, our Twitter account, and Youtube Channel.

The Impact

The central theme of these films is to challenge both the rising Islamophobia in the United States and conservative ideas within the Muslim community. We are hoping with these films to raise awareness about issues of gender equality, the complexities of the Muslim-American experience, and the potential for greater dialogue and respect within and among the various faith communities. 

While interfaith marriages between Muslim men and non-Muslims women are common, very few Muslim women exercise the same right. In fact, many people interviewed did not know or did not believe that Muslim women can marry outside the faith. The goal of the project is not to encourage Muslim women to marry outside of the faith, rather realize that they have the right to do so. Taking the U.S. as an example, Muslims represent roughly 1% of the whole population, which means according to the traditional interpretation, a Muslim woman cannot marry anyone out of the remaining 99% of Americans. Moreover, such restriction affects the integration of Muslims in their communities and legitimizes the anti-Islam rhetoric used by dangerous Islamophobes in the West.

Tell us your story or the story of a friend you may know who could/could not marry because of the false argument that Islam does not allow Muslim women to marry outside the faith. We are fully aware of the sensitivity of the topic, and if requested, your identity can remain anonymous.

Risks & Challenges

We, at Ibn Rushd Media, are fully aware of the immense risks and challenges that accompany such controversial and compounded project. Here are a few of these challenges:

1- Finding participants willing to share their personal story and face societal pressures as many participants do not want their stories to be told in public, fearing how their Muslim friends and families may judge them.

2- We are a startup company that is focusing on projects that are not necessarily profitable despite their significant impact, so funding will be a challenge. We managed to fund the first three films by ourselves, but the project is not close to being done and this is where you come in.

3- We are also facing the challenge of explaining to the majority of Muslims that, despite the common belief, Muslim women have the right to marry outside the faith, something that the majority of current Muslim clerics disagree with.

Mitigating the Risks:

1- We will protect the identity of any participant, unless they authorize us to use his or her name. If requested, we will also blur the faces of participants.

2- We are also reaching out to similar-minded organizations to coordinate efforts and resources to secure additional funding.

3- We are using the expertise of progressive Imams, who ground our work in sound theological and historical scholarship.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone interested in our cause can contribute money. If you cannot contribute money, we humbly request your help share our online discussions using the following:

1. Follow our Twitter account and tweet regularly about our campaign #HerRight2Marry

2. Like our Facebook page, share, and interact with our posts

3. Subscribe to our Youtube Channel

4. Sign up to be on our mailing list and forward our emails to your friends and family

story:
Check out our teaser:


THE STORY

“In a Dream” is a romantic comedy which merges the traditional sensibilities of a “Sleepless in Seattle” with a focus on the female lead’s perspective and the pitfalls of modern technological gadgetry. It combines something old with something new (maybe something borrowed, or blue?). In any case, we think that you will fall in love with it!

Your pledges will bring this movie into being, but more importantly, you’ll be helping us build a community of like-minded film lovers. We want to bring that community into the development process of our future projects and develop films that you, our audience, can truly connect with. 

PRODUCTION TIMELINE AND BUDGET

Production already started and we plan to finish by late Spring - then we will begin post production, which will entail editing, colorizing, some special effects (green screening) and adding a soundtrack.  We hope to be done with post production by the end the summer. 

All main cast and crew are donating their time - nobody is getting paid.  The money we are raising will go toward  equipment rentals, props, location permits and fees, production insurance, food and gas, and many others.  

THE TEAM

Edina Kishonthy, Writer-Director

Edina was born and raised in Hungary, where her coming-of-age novel, “Red Snow” (which she wrote in high school) became a cult favorite of her generation, and sold 10 thousand copies. She moved to Los Angeles to attend the Peter Stark Producing Program at the University of Southern California Film School. After completing the program, she went on to earn a second degree related to her other passion, psychotherapy, which has allowed her to create even more authentic characters with complex emotions and backstories. Edina has worked with a number of independent producers as a script doctor, and helped them get the most out of a screenplay while respecting the writer’s original vision. Lately, Edina’s film making skills were refined by her young daughter, who requires her to film her soap operas featuring Littlest Pet Shop figures.

Megan Barker, "Kate"

Originally from Little Rock Arkansas, Megan is a recent transplant to Los Angeles. She got into acting almost by accident: she took a drama class in high school because she needed an elective – and fell in love! She pursued theater through college and studied acting, as well as some technical aspects of the craft, such as costume and mask making.  She even went to Italy to learn the art of Commedia Dell'Arte, which included designing and molding traditional leather masks for the characters. Megan has been in many plays; her favorite acting experience has been embodying a character who had a Brooklyn accent and aged from 20 to 60 during the span of the performance. 

Lauren Pence, "Heather," Kate's best friend

Lauren Pence is an actress and writer based in Los Angeles. She studied Theatre and Original Works at Cornish College of the Arts in Seattle, and has acted in commercials for Amazon, AT&T and Map Quest. The short film she co-wrote and acted in, “Please Hand Stamp,” debuted at the Austin Film Festival. Lauren performs with the Yard Theatre Company, and this Spring, she launched her online Culture & Lifestyle magazine “My Two Pence” – with spotlights on independent designers, interesting LA happenings, trends in beauty, and tips on urban gardening.

Case Little, "Dream Man"

Case recently moved to Los Angeles following his graduation with a BFA in theatre performance from Virginia Commonwealth University. Growing up with a love for movies, he made his decision to move West to pursue a career in film and television. He has been diligently working to build his reel since arriving and has garnered a few credits on films by students at the New York Film Academy and UCLA. Apart from being on camera, Case enjoys exploring the city with his friends and doing all things to support a healthy lifestyle. Two of his favorite things are working out and going out -- and there is no shortage of either in this busy city. From the beaches to the different museums, Los Angeles has proven to be an exciting and adventurous new home for him.

Kevin Sinic, "Sleazy Guy"

Kevin was born and raised in Leibnitz, Austria. Initially a passionate semi-pro soccer player, he left home for good at age 24 to pursue his dreams and moved to the U.S. He received a full athletic scholarship to Felician University in Rutherford, New Jersey, where he earned a Bachelor of Arts in Communications, and fell in love with the craft of acting.  After graduating in 2012 he decided to move to Los Angeles to continue his acting career. He is currently in the master class at Anthony Gilardi’s acting studio. He is repped theatrically and commercially by The Firm LA and managed by TLynn Talent.  Kevin recently got cast in the indie feature “Guitars and Guns,” which will begin shooting in March.  In addition to acting, Kevin writes poetry and frequently performs spoken word.  His goal is to finish and publish a collection of his work by the end of 2016.

Vincent Patin, Director of Photography

Born and raised in Los Angeles, Vincent is a cinematographer and camera operator, as well as a member of the IATSE Local 600. Vincent has gained extensive feature film, short, commercial, documentary, and music video experience working with a variety of clients. An alumni of Loyola Marymount University's School of Film and Television, Vincent has fostered a deep love for storytelling and film making. His work has been seen at festivals around the world including Cannes, Sundance, and Slamdance. Vince has also received many accolades from top critics, such as "Striking!" - An electrician; and "My son is the best! He has an eye for the shot!" - His Mother. 

Teodora Chrystie, Producer

Like Edina, Teodora is also a graduate of the prestigious USC Peter Stark Producing Program, and has over 15 years of experience in the entertainment industry. She started out as an intern at Castle Rock Entertainment, where she prepared script coverage and story notes. During her time at American Entertainment Investors, Inc., a boutique consulting firm, she assisted in developing business plans for film and media investment ventures and constructing film performance models. As Director of Production and Development with River Road Entertainment (“Into the Wild,” “Fur”), she solicited and evaluated film proposals from agents, managers and talent, and also coordinated various physical production and business affairs issues related to film projects. Teodora has recently taken time off to focus on family, but has continued to develop personal projects and consult a number of companies and ventures. She is thrilled to get back to production with this project.

story:
Break It Down For Us


Being a confident women doesn't mean you have to be perfect . . . or even involve wearing matching clothes. And being reasonably successful in your 20s doesn't mean you won't get dead cat ashes mailed to your work place from little old ladies. These are some of the wonderful and weird insights we hope to bring forward with our new comedy, You Can Do Better.

Kayla Hairy, is a twenty four year old aspiring journalist, current cat obituary writer, hypochondriac and maybe the funniest, sweetest person you'll ever meet. We follow Kayla, in all the trouble her weirdness and un- containable confidence causes her to fall in to, head first and with her granny knickers showing.

This story is absurd but it also has a lot of heart like all good comedy does. But to make this come true we need money. With it, we'll be able to create the best quality web series for all of you, which is important to us, since you're who we want to enjoy it!

What We Need & What You Get

The money will be used for the usual suspects, paying cast and crew, equipment, craft services, locations, and money for all things post.
But the best part about this whole thing is that you get something back in return. We have numerous perks including personally written postcards, signed posters, your very own cat obituary with the cat name of your choice not to mention being able to visit us on set during a party episode!
Just know, no matter how much money we get it's all going towards producing episodes of great content!
Poster option 1, 2, 3

Tell Me More About The People Behind It


Sonibel Rae - WRITER/CREATOR/PRODUCER

Sonibel is currently studying Screenwriting at one of the top creative universities in England. In the four years she has set her sights on Screenwriting, her comedic work has been performed live on Hollywood Boulevard as part of the 3rd LA Scripted Comedy Festival, and has won numerous awards including BEST SERIES SCRIPT at The Indie Gathering International Film Festival. Her passion for filmmaking and under represented characters AND comedy caused her to create this series. Her comedy inspirations include the likes of Amy Sherman Palladino (Gilmore Girls), Mindy Kaling (The Office and The Mindy Project) and Diablo Cody (Juno, Young Adult). 


Rosemary Andrews - DIRECTOR/PRODUCER

Rosemary currently studies at Royal Holloway University, England. She specialises in Theatre Direction, having written and directed and even acted for the stage! This insight into actors makes her direction on shoots particularly helpful. She has also worked behind the camera on multiple projects ranging from creation of trailers to doing official photography for many Scouting events in South London. In her work co-producing and directing a pantomime in South London, she successfully developed comedic performances, co-ordinated with the light and sound team; liaising with the lightning and sound team and created a great work environment. Her directorial inspirations include Katheryn Bigelow (The Hurt Locker, Zero Dark Thirty), Amy Sherman Palladino (Gilmore Girls) and Shonda Rhimes (Grey's Anatomy, Scandal, almost every other show on TV).


Alicia McKenzie - ACTOR

Alicia plays the main character Kayla in the series. 

Alicia has acted in many theatre productions such as "Rapunzel", "The White Witch of Rose Hall" and "Ring a Ding Ding" which was performed in New York. She has also worked in feature films and the TV show Asylum.

Bhavnisha Parmar - ACTOR

Bhavnisha plays the role of Kayla's best friend and workaholic doctor, Amreeta, in the series. 

Bhavnisha Parmar, known for her roles in the TV movie Guilty Pleasures (2016) and the shorts Les Crabes Terribles (2014), Darren Has a Breakdown and Champion of the World (2012).

Nir Kitaro - ACTOR

Nir plays the role of long suffering neighbour Faizan. 

Nir has had great success, playing various roles in short films, American TV pilots and several theatre productions such as Avenue Q a major theatrical hit.


The Impact
While there have been great strides made in the comedy world with women in film, there is still a lack of representation in the comedy world for women of colour.
Our project is important as it shows that series about women of colour, and people of colour in general, do not have to have race as the over arching theme in order to be popular or worthy of viewing.
Our series is in many ways a romantic comedy, but with a racially diverse cast of characters and a quirky black woman at the forefront. This is important as its important to give characters of colour the same range of representation as white characters are afforded in media.
Our campaign is also providing work experience for youth in our local area for ages 16 and over to help them with their CV's and spark a love for filmmaking that could last a life time.

What Have You Got Done So Far?

Earlier this year we opened a mini gofundme campaign to get money to shoot our first two episodes, plus some excerpts from other episodes that could be used to form a trailer. With £400 pounds we spent two days shooting those scenes and have now cut them together in our trailer. With the extra money not only can we produce the rest of our episodes but also do more thorough post production on our footage which was not completely possible due to limited funds.
In addition to this we have launched accounts on Twitter, Facebook AND Instagram. Have THREE different sets of poster art to choose from. And recorded an original theme song for our series. We have been hard at work for months and we don't expect any of that to stop any time soon. We had our first production meeting back in August and we've been working towards this ever since. So, you can definitely see we're committed and have thought this project out . . . a lot!

Risks & Challenges

Every crowdfunding campaign has its challenges. For some it's their schedule of sending out perks. For others it's the wave of panic when their campaign goes so viral they don't know what to do with themselves or the extra cash that has come rolling in.
We are prepared for both instances. 
In the wonderful instance that you guys get us over that 100% mark, don't fret about where that extra money's going. No one here is going to be off buying big mansions. All extra money will go towards a SECOND season of our show. We love these characters and we know they have so many more exciting and funny storyline's for you all to enjoy. If we get over our goal, we'll store that money away so hopefully next time, we will ask for hardly anything or even better yet, we won't have to ask for anything at all.


Other Ways YOU Can Help

We know not everyone can contribute and guess what? That's totally okay! There are other ways to help us reach our goal which won't make any kind of impact on your bank account. Here are some of those ways:

  • Tell people about how much you love our campaign. Tell your co-workers, your mom, that cute guy at the coffee shop who kinda looks like Chris Evans. Who knows? They may be as excited for it as you (and us!) and end up donating!
  • Share our campaign on Twitter, Facebook and other social media!

And that's all there is to it.
