story:
Our Vision

Our vision is expand our generous and joyous Australian community to embrace the families of one small Balinese mountain village near Mt Batur. We want the children of this village to benefit from secure housing, high school education and future career opportunities, just as we want to learn from the example of their simple, cheerful sharing approach to life.

Such beautifully generous hospitality making us tea when obviously it is very precious.

About the village

These Balinese families live a simple, humble lifestyle with few opportunities to build a secure future. Rice farming is the main source of income although the farming season only lasts three months and the farmers are hired to work the land rather than owning the rice fields. There are few opportunities for earning money and limited opportunities for education. While the government provides assistance for children to attend primary school, there is no government assistance for high school. Also there are no high schools in the mountains so parents face the additional cost of travel.

One rice farmer lives with his wife, father and four young daughters in a makeshift hut built after their original home blew down in a storm. Outside the farming season, his only means of income is wood carving – he can make one carving a day, valued at one dollar. He wants his four daughters – twins aged 10, and twins aged 4 – to be able to go to high school when they are older but he does not know how that will be possible.

Another villager is a bike tour guide and the father of two daughters. He dreams of becoming a driver tour guide yet saving to purchase a car is near impossible.

            Kitchen floods in wet weather.

Our Mission

We want to raise $5000 to help this family build a strong durable home on the site of their original home. Any additional funds raised will go towards a sponsorship program for the children of the village so they can attend high school.

The family are proud and humble people, so they wish to remain anonymous. For the same reason, we cannot share the name of the village. However, we do have permission to provide photos so you can see the results of your generosity.   

This picture shows the ancient foundations to the families home in the village that collapsed in a storm. 


*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*



The Full long version! (if you have time to read!...more pictures at the end)

A most humble experience.

In October 2014 I headed over to Bali for my Birthday with a friend of mine, My friend has been to Bali many times and assured me that all the negative talk about 9 Australians dying every month over there was Media Hype..Bali is her sacred healing place and she spoke so highly of the humble culture and beautiful healing land. She soon had me convinced so off I went with an open heart and I am so so grateful that I did.

While over there I took myself off on a 30km bike tour from Mt Batur to Ubud. My friend had already done this ride on one of her previous trips and so I decided i would go alone. The day before I went I met a lovely Australian / English woman, at the Motel. I convinced her to join me and what a day we had!

Our Tour guides  were amazing. I was really taken at how well one guide could speak English of which he was incredibly proud. We struck up a lovely friendship and I am excited to say that he has invited me to come and stay in his village with his wife and 2 daughters when I return in March. I am most excited at this because being a tourist and being part of a village community are two entirely different things.

(I will elaborate on our sibling like friendship later!)

While on our ride he shared with us all about his ancient culture and the way the Balinese mountain villagers live. I felt I was receiving a precious insight into a most humble beautiful people.I felt in awe of the beauty both in the visual surrounds and also within the people. Such love pours from their eyes it was very humbling an experience for me.

We stopped at a Rice farmers home. Our guide explained that the tour company he works for helps support these farmers families with their children’s school accessories like books, pens etc for allowing their home and life to be shown to 'tourists'. I felt awkward at first , as if I was trespassing But the warmth and welcoming embrace that I received from the farmers wife was incredible. She made us refreshing tea in glasses and it was clear that the tea is precious . Money and belongings were barely existent. Our guide explained that this beautiful family (Grandpa, Father, Mother, twin girls age 10 and twin girls age 4) were living on the same ground that had been their ancestors for possibly hundreds of years. He explained that their incredibly meagre dwelling was makeshift as their home had blown down in a storm. He showed us the foundations of where their home once stood and it was no larger then my kitchen! (see Pictures)

Their cooking was one clay pot over an earth brick fire, Water carried via buckets from the river and walls made of packing crates and sacks,Yet they had such humble joy and shared with us their precious tea .

I sat and watched with a huge lump in my throat . Thoughts drifted in and out

”I will never complain again”

“I love my toilet I will never whinge that it needs cleaning ever again”

”OMG I love my bed and my soft pillows”

“the luxury of running water, both hot and cold”...

My head was whirling as our guides talk drifted in and out.

I knew I could help in some way.

The little 4 year old identical twins smiles twinkled at me and there was an instant love affair happening as the rest of the group were fixated on our guides speech.

I looked deep into the mothers eyes and she saw I had tears. She shuffled closer and held my hand for a moment. This memory still brings a lump to my throat. I found a dollar in my pocket as I had not brought my bag.. I subtly handed it to her.She did not want to take it and I gestured it was for the young twins and so she obliged with such a humbleness.

Our guide soon had us all on our bikes and I found the rest of the journey on the ride I spent thinking of how I could somehow help this struggling family.

Our guide explained to me at the end of the trip after much probing that Rice farming is only 3 months of the year. The farmers don’t own the land, they are just the workers and are some of the poorest people in Bali. Once Rice season is finished they have to survive in what ever way they can. This beautiful families father had learned the art of wood carving and had mastered one carving type, a seahorse that he could produce one per day . He raised the equivalent of one Australian dollar per day for these carvings!

I asked our guide how much would it cost to rebuild their dwelling considering the foundations are still there, (see pictures) he replied $500 for 4 poles and straw roof or $5000 for a proper building with walls and windows. I asked how long would it take them to do this as I am concerned about the wet season coming. He said "they just wont be able to do it, they wont ever save that sort of money."

I felt deeply saddened and said to our guide I am going to do what ever I can to help them get a roof over their head.

My friend (our guide) and I have continued to keep in touch, We are face-book friends (yes they have internet!) I feel privileged and he has shared a lot with me about his life as well.He lives as a bike tour guide, his dream is to own a car one day and be a driver tour guide. He has two daughters one in primary and one in high school.

In Bali the government assist families for primary education but not high school.

There are no high schools in the mountains and so it is a huge stress for families to afford the cost of high school and deal with the travel to and from so many are unable to get more then a primary school education.He is determined to get his girls through high school and it clearly is very difficult. 

Not long after I arrived home he had a pushbike accident and broke his wrist, he was so humble that he said he was in pain but the village healer was looking after him. He could not afford to get it treated in hospital. It was only a week or so a go that I was asking how he was healing , he said he is back at work which I was delighted to hear ,then he sent me a photo of his wrist and my heart plummeted. It is clearly still broken and shows a clear deformity now in the bone. I struggled to comprehend how he could still be riding a bike with his wrist like this.(see picture)

I have made a commitment to now raise money to build the dwelling for the beautiful rice farming family and if there is any change I would like to support our guides daughters getting through their high school by covering some of their fees etc.

The idea of the Fundraiser has been birthed out of this experience.

I chose Valentines day because it is a day devoted to the power of Love. What better a day to raise money and share some of the abundance that is in our lives.

Thank you all from the bottom of my heart …

With mountains of Love and Gratitude,

Kerry  

I know my back would not like sitting carving like that all day.

Grandfather and young twin sweetie making music together..melt my heart.

Rice fields .. so beautiful.

Devastating photo of our guides apparently 'healed' wrist.

She soon had me convinced so off I went with an open heart and I am
so so grateful that I did.

While over there I took myself off on a
30km bike tour from Mt Batur to Ubud. My friend had already
done this ride on one of her previous trips and so I decided i would
go alone. The day before I went I met a lovely
Australian / English woman, at the Motel.  I convinced her to
join me and what a day we had!

Our Tour guides  were
amazing. I was really taken at how well one guide could speak English of
which he was incredibly proud. We struck up a lovely friendship and I
am excited to say that he has invited me to come and stay in his
village with his wife and 2 daughters when I return in March. I am
most excited at this because being a tourist and being part of a
village community are two entirely different things.
 (I will elaborate on our sibling like friendship later!)

While on our ride he shared with us
all about his ancient culture and the way the Balinese  mountain
villagers live. I felt I was receiving a precious
insight into a most humble beautiful people.I felt in awe of the beauty both in the
visual surrounds and also within the people. Such love pours from
their eyes it was very humbling an experience for me.

We stopped at a Rice farmers home. Our guide explained that the tour company he works for helps support
these farmers families with their children’s school accessories
like books, pens etc for allowing their home and life to be shown to
'tourists'. I felt awkward at first , as if I was trespassing  But
the warmth and welcoming embrace that I received from the farmers
wife was incredible. She made us refreshing tea in glasses and it was
clear that the tea is precious . Money and belongings were barely
existent. Our guide explained that this beautiful family (Grandpa,
Father, Mother, twin girls age 10 and twin girls age 4) were living
on the same ground that had been their ancestors for possibly
hundreds of years. He explained that their incredibly meagre dwelling
was makeshift as their home had blown down in a storm. He showed us
the foundations of where their home once stood and it was no larger
then my kitchen! (see Pictures)
Their cooking was one clay pot over an
earth brick fire, Water carried via buckets from the river and walls
made of packing crates and sacks,Yet they had such humble joy and
shared with us their precious tea .
I sat and watched with a huge lump in
my throat . Thoughts drifted in and out 

”I will never complain again”
“I love my toilet I will never whinge
that it needs cleaning ever again”
”OMG I love my bed and my soft
pillows”
“the luxury of running water, both
hot and cold”...
My head was whirling as our guides talk
drifted in and out.

I knew I could help in some way.
The little 4 year old identical twins
smiles twinkled at me and there was an instant love affair happening
as the rest of the group were fixated on our guides speech.
I looked deep into the mothers eyes and
she saw I had tears. She shuffled closer and held my hand for a
moment. This memory still brings a lump to my throat. I found a
dollar in my pocket as I had not brought my bag.. I subtly handed it
to her.She did not want to take it and I gestured it was for the
young twins and so she obliged with such a humbleness.

Our guide soon had us all on our bikes and
I found the rest of the journey on the ride I spent thinking of how I
could somehow help this struggling family.
Our guide explained to me at the end of the
trip after much probing that Rice farming is only 3 months of the
year. The farmers don’t own the land, they are just the workers and
are some of the poorest people in Bali. Once Rice season is finished
they have to survive in what ever way they can. This beautiful
families father had learned the art of wood carving and had mastered
one carving type, a seahorse that he could produce one per day . He raised the equivalent of one Australian dollar per day for these
carvings!

I asked our guide how much would it cost to
rebuild their dwelling considering the foundations are still there,
(see pictures) he replied $500 for 4 poles and straw roof or
$5000 for a proper building with walls and windows. I asked how long
would it take them to do this as I am concerned about the wet season
coming. He said "they just wont be able to do it, they wont ever save
that sort of money."
I felt deeply saddened and said to our guide I am going to do what ever I can to help them get a roof over
their head. 


My friend (our guide) and I have continued to keep in
touch, We are face-book friends (yes they have internet!) I feel privileged and he has
shared a lot with me about his life as well.He lives as a bike tour guide, his
dream is to own a car one day and be a driver tour guide. He has two
daughters one in primary and one in high school.
In Bali the government assist families
for primary education but not high school.
There are no high schools in the
mountains and so it is a huge stress for families to afford the cost
of high school and deal with the travel to and from so many are
unable to get more then a primary school education.He is determined to get his girls
through high school and it clearly is very difficult. Not long after
I arrived home he had a pushbike accident and broke his wrist, he was
so humble that he said he was in pain but the village healer was
looking after him. He could not afford to get it treated in hospital.
It was only a week or so a go that I was asking how he was healing ,
he said he is back at work which I was delighted to hear ,then he
sent me a photo of his wrist and my heart plummeted. It is clearly
still broken and shows a clear deformity now in the bone. I struggled
to comprehend how he could still be riding a bike with his wrist like
this.(see picture)

I have made a commitment to now raise
money to build the dwelling for the beautiful rice farming family and
if there is any change I would like to support our guides daughters
getting through their high school by covering some of their fees etc.

The idea of the Fundraiser has been
birthed out of this experience.

I chose Valentines day because it is a
day devoted to the power of Love. What better a day to raise money
and share some of the abundance that is in our lives.

Thank you all from the bottom of my
heart …




With mountains of Love and Gratitude,

Kerry  I know my back would not like sitting carving like that all day.Grandfather and young twin sweetie making music together..melt my heart.Rice fields .. so beautiful.Devastating photo of our guides apparently 'healed' wrist.
